units.core_reframe: The nervous system that learned to scan for danger in the past does not automatically know when the danger has passed — it keeps the alarm running as a form of protection, even when the threat is gone.
question_bank: When did you first learn that the world required this level of alertness?
What would it actually feel like to feel safe — not logically know you're safe, but feel it?
What is the vigilance protecting you from that you don't want to be unprotected from?
What has the constant readiness cost you in terms of rest, presence, or connection?
units.short_reframe: The alarm that kept you safe then doesn't know that 'then' is over.
units.short_question: What would it feel like to actually feel safe — not just know you are?
units.rewire_target: Develop nervous system awareness — distinguish past threat from present reality.

units.core_reframe: The thing that happened to you is real. And carrying it as the most central fact of who you are is a choice — one that made sense for a while, and may be worth examining now.
question_bank: Who are you in addition to what happened to you?
What would you explore about yourself if the difficult past weren't the primary lens?
What parts of you existed before this — and are any of them still here?
What would it mean to carry this lightly — not to erase it, but not to be organized by it?
units.short_reframe: What happened to you is part of your story — the question is how much of the page it gets.
units.short_question: Who are you that exists separately from what you survived?
units.rewire_target: Develop post-traumatic identity — self-concept that includes but isn't organized around the wound.

units.core_reframe: Numbness is not the absence of feeling — it is feeling's protection strategy. When things became too much, the system dimmed the signal. The dimness is itself a sign of how much was once felt.
question_bank: When did you first notice that you'd stopped feeling things the way you used to?
What feeling, if it came back, would you be most afraid of?
What did the numbness originally protect you from — and is that protection still necessary?
Is there anywhere in your life where feeling still gets through — even slightly?
units.short_reframe: Numbness is the system's way of surviving what feeling couldn't hold — it was protection, not absence.
units.short_question: What feeling, if it returned, would you be most afraid to have back?
units.rewire_target: Restore emotional contact — gradual, safe return to felt experience.

units.core_reframe: The person who learned that trust leads to betrayal built the most rational wall possible — and then found themselves alone inside it, which became its own kind of pain.
question_bank: What would have to be true about a person for you to trust them — have you ever articulated that?
What is the difference between choosing who to trust carefully and deciding trust itself is unavailable?
What has the wall kept out that you didn't want kept out?
What would you risk by letting someone in slightly — just slightly — further than you currently do?
units.short_reframe: The wall that kept out betrayal also kept out connection — both things are true.
units.short_question: What has the wall kept out that you didn't actually want kept out?
units.rewire_target: Rebuild selective trust — distinguishing blanket self-protection from discerning openness.

units.core_reframe: Perfectionism is not the love of excellence — it is the terror of being found inadequate, dressed up as high standards.
question_bank: What are you afraid would be revealed about you if the work were imperfect and visible?
What is the belief underneath 'it has to be perfect'?
Whose voice does the inner critic sound like when it says it's not good enough?
What have you not started or not finished because the standard felt impossible from the beginning?
units.short_reframe: The drive for perfect is rarely about the work — it's about what imperfect says about you.
units.short_question: What would imperfect work say about you that you can't tolerate?
units.rewire_target: Distinguish excellence from perfectionism — high standards from fear-based impossibility.

units.core_reframe: Leaving things unfinished keeps them permanently possible — a finished thing can be judged, found lacking, or simply be over. Incompleteness is sometimes a way of staying safe from the verdict.
question_bank: What happens in your imagination the moment something is done and visible to others?
Is there a pattern of things that get 90% complete and then stall?
What does finishing something take away that unfinished keeps available?
What is the fear that arrives right at the edge of completion?
units.short_reframe: The unfinished thing cannot be judged — which is sometimes exactly why it stays unfinished.
units.short_question: What would finishing take away that staying almost-done keeps safely available?
units.rewire_target: Identify and dissolve completion anxiety — separate the act of finishing from the fear of judgment.

theme_tags: if i can't do it perfectly why bother
units.core_reframe: The mind that decides between perfect and pointless has removed the entire middle range where most of real life happens.
question_bank: What would 'good enough for now' look like — and why does that feel like failure?
What have you abandoned because it couldn't meet the standard you set at the beginning?
What is the cost of the all-or-nothing standard in terms of things that never got to exist at all?
What would you begin if 'okay' were an acceptable place to start?
units.short_reframe: Between perfect and pointless is where everything real actually gets done.
units.short_question: What would you begin if 'okay' was an acceptable place to start?
units.rewire_target: Develop graduated standards — the capacity to value effort and progress rather than only outcome.

units.core_reframe: The person who can never say no has made everyone else's comfort more important than their own reality — and usually learned this was necessary before they were old enough to know it was a choice.
question_bank: When did you first learn that keeping others comfortable was your responsibility?
What do you imagine would happen to the relationship if you said no?
What has never saying no cost you that you haven't fully accounted for?
What would the version of you who said no occasionally look and feel like?
units.short_reframe: The inability to disappoint others is often the inability to be honest with them.
units.short_question: What do you imagine would actually happen if you said no?
units.rewire_target: Develop authentic relating — moving from appeasement-based interaction to honest engagement.

units.core_reframe: The belief that conflict destroys relationships is often the belief that the relationship is too fragile to survive honesty — which is itself a statement about the relationship worth examining.
question_bank: What do you believe conflict means for a relationship — what's the catastrophic version in your mind?
What relationships in your life have survived honest disagreement — and what did that teach you?
Is the peace you're maintaining real, or is it the surface over something building underneath?
What would you say if you believed the relationship could hold it?
units.short_reframe: The relationship you're protecting from conflict might be the one that most needs it.
units.short_question: What would you say if you believed the relationship was strong enough to hold it?
units.rewire_target: Develop conflict tolerance — distinguishing productive disagreement from relationship destruction.

units.core_reframe: There is a version of selflessness that is genuinely generous — and a version that is the self, erased, calling it virtue.
question_bank: When someone asks what you want — what happens in the moment before you answer?
What do you actually prefer, enjoy, and want — separate from what makes others comfortable?
How long could you articulate your own preferences without referencing someone else's?
When did your own desires start feeling like a disruption rather than a legitimate voice?
units.short_reframe: Selflessness that requires erasing yourself isn't generosity — it's a different kind of loss.
units.short_question: What do you actually want — not what works for everyone, what you want?
units.rewire_target: Recover self-knowledge — distinguishing genuine generosity from self-erasure under the label of care.

units.core_reframe: The exhaustion of being around people isn't about people — it's about the energy cost of managing the gap between who you are and who you're presenting.
question_bank: How wide is the gap between who you are in public and who you are alone?
Is there anyone with whom the gap fully closes — and what makes that possible?
What would you stop doing in social situations if you trusted people to stay anyway?
What part of yourself have you been keeping out of sight for so long it feels dangerous to show?
units.short_reframe: The tiredness after being with people is the gap between the you that showed up and the you that stayed behind.
units.short_question: Who is the you that stayed home while the other version went to be with people?
units.rewire_target: Reduce identity performance — move toward authentic self-presentation in safe relationships.

units.core_reframe: Children who blame themselves for what was done to them are not wrong to look for a cause — but they are looking in the only place they feel they have control, which is themselves.
question_bank: What did blaming yourself give you that external blame couldn't — in terms of feeling some control?
If a child came to you with this exact story and blamed themselves, what would you say?
What would it mean about your world if you weren't responsible for what happened?
What does carrying the responsibility protect you from having to feel about the person who actually held it?
units.short_reframe: Self-blame in powerless situations is the mind trying to find some control — even a painful one.
units.short_question: What would you need to feel about them if the blame weren't yours to carry?
units.rewire_target: Redistribute responsibility accurately — release self-blame without collapsing into victimhood.

units.core_reframe: The inner critic speaks with great authority and very rarely with accuracy — it is a protective voice that learned harshness as a style before it learned anything else.
question_bank: Whose voice does the inner critic most resemble?
What is the inner critic actually trying to protect you from?
If you spoke to someone you loved the way the inner critic speaks to you, what would that look like?
Has the inner critic's harshness ever actually produced the improvement it promises — or just the pain?
units.short_reframe: The harshest voice inside you learned its tone before it had any choice about it.
units.short_question: Whose voice does the inner critic sound like — and when did you take over running it yourself?
units.rewire_target: Develop inner critic awareness — understanding its origin and separating its voice from truth.
